Scales

Scales are used to normalise values of projects; few people can tell if a value of 2.3 violations per thousands of lines of code is high, fair or low. In order to help people understand and better grasp the meaning and consequences of the values, a 5-level scale has been setup. These pages give more information on the selection of thresholds for all metrics, sorted according to their origin (repository).

  • Grimoire metrics

    Grimoire is an open-source toolset produced by Bitergia that obtains data from various software repositories: source code management, issue tracking systems, communication in mailing lists, etc. Data is stored in a SQL database and can easily be retrieved to present awesome statistics on the development process. There is a dedicated dashboard for Eclipse at dashboard.eclipse.org that already analyses thousands of projects.

    Get more details about Grimoire scales

  • Marketplace metrics

    The Eclipse marketplace lists the products and companies that make the Eclipse ecosystem. Users can also directly install plugins from the marketplace into their own IDE by a single drag'n'drop.

    Get more details about Marketplace scales

  • PMI metrics

    The Project Management Infrastructure (or PMI) is an Eclipse project which goal is to maintain a repository of meta-information for all projects. We use it to retrieve planning management information, and amount of information available for the SCM and ITS repositories.

    Get more details about PMI scales

  • Rule-checking metrics

    We use open-source software like PMD and FindBugs to analyse coding practices. Each rule is tagged with one or more quality attribute it impacts, and a severity.

    Get more details about Rule-Checking scales

  • SonarQube metrics

    SonarQube provides source code metrics for projects. There is a dedicated instance of SonarQube within the Eclipse foundation, and projects are welcome to use it.

    Get more details about SonarQube scales
